slides.tip: Decimals are just another way to write fractions - think of money as an everyday example!

slides.title: What are Decimals?
slides.content:
A decimal is a number that has a decimal point (.) separating the whole number from the fractional part.

Parts of a decimal:

  • Whole number part: The digits before the decimal point
  • Decimal point: The dot (.) that separates whole and fractional parts
  • Decimal part: The digits after the decimal point

Example: 3.75

  • 3 = whole number
  • . = decimal point
  • 75 = decimal part (seventy-five hundredths)
slides.example:
Reading Decimals:

  • 0.5 = "zero point five" or "five-tenths"
  • 2.3 = "two point three" or "two and three-tenths"
  • 15.75 = "fifteen point seven five" or "fifteen and seventy-five hundredths"

Money Example:

GHâ‚µ12.50 = 12 cedis and 50 pesewas
slides.tip: The decimal point is like a fence - it separates whole numbers from parts of numbers!

slides.title: Decimal Place Value
slides.content:
Each position after the decimal point has a specific place value:

PositionPlace ValueExample
1st placeTenths (1/10)0.5
2nd placeHundredths (1/100)0.25
3rd placeThousandths (1/1000)0.125

Example: 4.567

  • 4 = ones place
  • 5 = tenths place (5/10)
  • 6 = hundredths place (6/100)
  • 7 = thousandths place (7/1000)
slides.example:
Understanding Place Value:

0.3 = 3 tenths = 3/10

0.25 = 25 hundredths = 25/100

0.125 = 125 thousandths = 125/1000

Which is bigger?

  • 0.7 vs 0.07: 0.7 is bigger (7 tenths > 7 hundredths)
  • 0.5 vs 0.49: 0.5 is bigger (50 hundredths > 49 hundredths)
slides.tip: Add zeros to make comparing easier: 0.7 = 0.70, so you can see 0.70 > 0.07!

slides.title: Converting Fractions to Decimals
slides.content:
To convert a fraction to a decimal, divide the numerator by the denominator.

Steps:

  1. Set up the division: numerator Ã· denominator
  2. Add a decimal point and zeros to the numerator
  3. Divide until you get a remainder of zero or a repeating pattern

Common Conversions to Memorize:

  • 1/2 = 0.5
  • 1/4 = 0.25
  • 3/4 = 0.75
  • 1/5 = 0.2
  • 1/10 = 0.1

slides.title: Adding & Subtracting Decimals
slides.content:
Adding and subtracting decimals is just like whole numbers - line up the decimal points!

Steps:

  1. Write the numbers vertically
  2. Line up the decimal points
  3. Add zeros if needed to make the same length
  4. Add or subtract as normal
  5. Bring the decimal point straight down
slides.example:
Addition Example: 12.5 + 3.75

  12.50  (added zero)
+  3.75
-------
  16.25

Subtraction Example: 8.3 - 2.45

  8.30  (added zero)
- 2.45
------
  5.85

Money Example:

GHâ‚µ15.50 + GHâ‚µ7.25 = GHâ‚µ22.75
slides.tip: Always line up the decimal points like soldiers in a row - this prevents mistakes!

slides.title: Multiplying Decimals
slides.content:
Multiplying decimals has one extra step at the end!

Steps:

  1. Ignore the decimal points and multiply normally
  2. Count total decimal places in both numbers
  3. Put the decimal point in the answer with that many places
